Hello all,



Many of you ask us about other programs where you can spread the word about GSoC and Open source to your universities. We wanted to pass along an opportunity to help spread more open source knowledge in your universities and learn about many Google technologies to help you and your colleagues in your careers.



If you are still a university student with another 1.5-2 years of university left, you might be interested in being a lead for Developer Student Clubs, a Google Developers community program that launched in 2017 and is currently available to students in most countries (currently not available in China or Japan).



Developer Student Clubs are university based community groups for students interested in Google developer technologies. Students from all undergraduate or graduate programs with an interest in growing as a developer are welcome. By joining a DSC, students grow their knowledge in a peer-to-peer learning environment and build solutions for local businesses and their community.


Developer Student Clubs have already:

Reached 195k student developers

Started 860+ chapters in 68 countries

Organized 3,350+ technical events globally



Do you want to open a Developer Student Club chapter at your university? Join the community of 860 chapters around the world.


Why should you join?

Grow your developer skills

Gain leadership experience

Impact other students by training them

Build solutions for local problems in the community

Be a part of a global network

Gain access to Google technology and platforms

Get invitations to select Google events and conferences

Attend a DSC Leads Summit and meet other leads and Googlers


Fill out the interest form here. Interest forms close May 15, 2020 at 11:59pm, PST.


Feel free to share this email with other student developers or share the announcement from the official @GoogleDevelopers: Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, and/or Blog.


To learn more visit
developers.google.com/community/dsc

Dear Sir/Madam,

Technology landscape has emerged out, in the past few weeks with value proposition for online meetings and video conferencing. Most of us are using available communication/networking platforms. These platforms share a majority in terms of usage but there are issues of data security, data breaching. Servers used for data storage are in different countries as they are not indigenous. Looking at this situation at a glance, there is an urge to create an Indigenous App as a solution.

Hence, Bharatiya Shikshan Mandal Yuva Ayam, Research For Resurgence Foundation and IIT Ropar jointly organizes Mobile Based Cloud Video Conferencing Competition to develop indigenous platform working on the basis of Data Pooling with no or minimal Dependence on large server, Beta version demo for minimum 50 users.

Winner will be awarded 5,00,000/-( Five Lakh Rupees Only) along with Development Support
3 Runner ups will get Internship from IIT Ropar
Last Date For :
Proposal Submission: 15th May 2020
Beta version Demo: 31st May 2020

For more details visit : http://rfrfoundation.org/competitions/


PFA:- https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ibJk62Mo3t_kS_kntN9-AzN7KFm7mKHE/view?usp=sharing

Regards

Dear all,
Hope you all are safe and well.
"Hacking just means building something quickly or testing the boundaries of what can be done. "  
                       -Mark Zuckerberg

Hacking is not a crime, it's a profession till the time one plays with it safely. There are always boundaries to be maintained, that's the rule every professional obey. Here at Ahmedabad University, the IEEE WIE Student branch is providing you with a webinar that would introduce you to those boundaries. 
 Learning from the finest in the field,Niralee Chavda. In the 90 minutes of conversation withNiralee Chavdalets get some inside secrets from someone who has good experience of corporate-level training in Infrastructure and security. Having 4 years of experience in Networking and server. Alongside being a Red hat certified Trainer, she has had the opportunity to work with technicians from all-round engineering disciplines has allowed her to troubleshoot complex system-level issues adding more to her bag of experience. Her job includes getting freshers job-ready and onboard for industry project work. This would be an advantage for all attendees to learn from the perspective of the corporate world.For more information about the speaker kindly refer to the pdf attached.

This being an opportunity which one can hardly miss, register yourself and save a seat. Learning these things without guidance can be a hassle. For everyone who wants to gain any knowledge, this just could be the kickstart to an amazing journey.
All relevant details are as follows
Speaker: Niralee Chavda
Date: May 13th, 2020
Day: Wednesday
Time: 3:00 PM to 4:30PM
Registration Link: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeOsUJQKRMMekN3tk7xYrCXCt1xGyXXHA7wSikY-ok5Xc0CLg/viewform?usp=sf_link

What is Psoc?
Psoc is an online internship platform for developing open source projects for the next two months. The projects will be reviewed by experts in the domain and the mentees will then be able to submit proposal for those projects. Selected mentees will get an exclusive opportunity to contribute to live projects under the guidance of experienced mentors.
This program is meant to create awareness about open-source and give opportunity to budding programmers.

See you onboard.

Let's admit it, online classes are quite boring now!
So instead of watching a duck race at 2 am, Listen to the ones who actually did it - LIVE 'CodeCast' on Youtube to realign your preparation to make the real difference.

IEEE brings you a podcast, on our IEEE channel with JIIT's alumni: Mr. Anmol Mishra, Associate SDE at Expedia, Ms. Kanishka Garg, Incoming Analyst at Goldman Sachs and Mr. Prakhar Gupta, SDE at Amazon along with IT Bodhi's Founder Mr. Amar Chauhan who will be discussing everything about preparation for top placements, career strategies, resources to follow and a lot more!

So set the reminder for 26th January, 12PM and get ready to acquire maximum knowledge from the experts.
Stay tuned and get your list of questions ready !

*CodeKart* *Hiring*

The ideal candidate will be responsible for conceptualizing and executing clear, quality code to develop the best software. You will test your code, identify errors, and iterate to ensure quality code. You will also support our customers and partners by troubleshooting any of their software issues. 
 
Responsibilities
1. Detect and troubleshoot software issues
2. Write clear quality code for software and applications and perform test reviews
3. Develop, implement, and test APIs
4. Provide input on software development projects

Qualifications
1. Comfort using technologies like React, Node, Express, MongoDB
2. Having basic knowledge about AWS and Docker
3. Strong debugging and troubleshooting skills
4. 1.5+ years' of development experience

Location
Bhubaneswar, Odisha

Interested persons can send their resume to careers@thecodekart.com

Pls Note : Freshers with some hands on experience on ReactJs and NodeJs can also apply.

But  please share the some sample website demo, if possible.


Thanks & Regards,
Krishna Agrawal

We are now accepting applications for the NVIDIA Graduate Fellowship Program for the 2022-2023 academic year!

The program, now in its 21st year, advances the frontiers of science by awarding grants and providing technical support to graduate students who are doing outstanding GPU-related research.

Were especially seeking doctoral students pushing the envelope in accelerated computing, artificial intelligence, robotics, autonomous vehicles, and related fields. Awards are for up to $50,000 per student and will be awarded in the 2022-2023 academic year.

Since its inception in 2002, the NVIDIA Graduate Fellowship Program has awarded 175 Ph.D. graduate students with grants that have helped accelerate their research efforts. More importantly, this funding has helped some students achieve major breakthroughs in their research  ones that may not have been possible without additional funding.

The program is open to applicants worldwide. The deadline for submitting applications is September 10, 2021. Eligible graduate students will have already completed their first year of Ph.D.-level studies at the time of application in the areas of computer science, computer engineering, system architecture, electrical engineering, or a related area. In addition, applicants must also be available to complete a summer internship prior to the start of their fellowship year.

Please share this opportunity with your departments, students, and friends.

For more information on eligibility and how to apply, visit
https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/research/graduate-fellowships.

Hello guys, as we are currently seeing recession in the IT field.

Just wanted to provide some thoughts from the Go Careers side.

First of all please don't worry, there are still many companies which are hiring.

We will try to regularly post about such companies.

Also this recession/lay-offs were expected since lot of hiring has been done in 2020 and 2021, which resulted in increase in cost for the companies and revenue generated was not enough.

Focus on learning new skills and also improve your current skills. Since IT field is a skill based field so the more you are good with such skills the more you will be in demand.

Atlast just B+

:)

We are hiring! 
 
Job Description: Senior Frontend Engineer Focused on React and Angular 
 
Our company, Anyforsoft, is seeking a Senior Frontend Engineer with a focus on React and Angular to join our team. As a Senior Frontend Engineer, you will be responsible for designing, developing, and testing dynamic web applications using React and Angular frameworks. You will work closely with our development team, UX/UI designers, and graphic designers to deliver consistent and reliable web applications. 
 
Responsibilities: 
Design, develop, and test dynamic web applications using React and Angular frameworks 
Collaborate with UX/UI designers and graphic designers to deliver consistent and reliable web applications 
Ensure high performance on mobile and desktop 
Identify issues with front-end code and rectify them to remove bugs 
Create and apply design planning 
Design new applications and websites 
Work on coding assignments and code reviews for functionality and accuracy 
Train team members and mentor junior developers with delegated tasks 
 
Required Skills: 
Proficiency in React and Angular frameworks 
Strong knowledge of JavaScript and TypeScript 
Excellent communication and collaboration skills 
Agile work practice experience 
6+ years of experience in frontend development focused on Angular and React.js 
 
Company Introduction: 
Anyforsoft is a leading software development company that specializes in creating efficient, scalable, and maintainable web applications. We value an open mind, collaboration, and ownership in our team. We work closely with our clients to deliver lasting value and provide services that implement complex technologies agilely and successfully. 
we are going to migrate our current React website into Angular. 
If you are a Senior Frontend Engineer with a focus on React and Angular and are passionate about using these frameworks to create visually aesthetic user interfaces, we encourage you to apply for this position. Apply with your latest CV. 
 
Contact @jaimehoo for the hiring process. 
Thank you.

Some common Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA) questions that are often asked in **Amazon** interviews for the Software Development Engineer **__(SDE-1)__** role:

1. **Arrays and Strings:**
   - Find the longest substring without repeating characters.
   - Rotate an array to the right by k steps.
   - Implement a function to perform string compression using counts of repeated characters.

2. **Linked Lists:**
   - Reverse a linked list.
   - Detect a cycle in a linked list.
   - Merge two sorted linked lists.

3. **Stacks and Queues:**
   - Implement a queue using two stacks.
   - Evaluate a postfix expression.
   - Design a stack that supports push, pop, top, and retrieving the minimum element in constant time.

4. **Trees and Graphs:**
   - Check if a binary tree is a valid binary search tree (BST).
   - Find the lowest common ancestor (LCA) of two nodes in a binary tree.
   - Implement a graph traversal algorithm (BFS or DFS).

5. **Sorting and Searching:**
   - Implement the quicksort or mergesort algorithm.
   - Find the kth largest element in an array.
   - Search for a given value in a sorted and rotated array.

6. **Dynamic Programming:**
   - Find the maximum subarray sum.
   - Count the number of unique paths in a grid.
   - Longest increasing subsequence.

7. **Design Problems:**
   - Design a Least Recently Used (LRU) cache.
   - Design a data structure that supports insert, delete, get random element operations in constant time.
   - Implement a trie (prefix tree) for efficient word insertions and searches.

8. **Bit Manipulation:**
   - Count the number of set bits in an integer.
   - Find the single non-repeated element in an array where every other element appears twice.
   - Reverse the bits of a given integer.

Here are some common Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA) questions that are often asked in **Microsoft** interviews for the Software Development Engineer (**SDE - 1**) role:

1. **Arrays and Strings:**
   - Find the longest palindromic substring in a given string.
   - Implement an algorithm to rotate a matrix by 90 degrees.
   - Merge overlapping intervals and return the resulting intervals.

2. **Linked Lists:**
   - Add two numbers represented by two linked lists.
   - Find the intersection point of two linked lists.
   - Partition a linked list around a given value.

3. **Stacks and Queues:**
   - Implement a stack using queues.
   - Design a data structure that supports retrieving the maximum element in a stack.
   - Implement a circular queue.

4. **Trees and Graphs:**
   - Serialize and deserialize a binary tree.
   - Check if a given graph is a tree or not.
   - Find the shortest path in a grid with obstacles.

5. **Sorting and Searching:**
   - Implement the merge sort or quicksort algorithm.
   - Search in a sorted and rotated array.
   - Find the peak element in an array.

6. **Dynamic Programming:**
   - Find the minimum path sum in a triangle.
   - Count the number of ways to decode a message (similar to the 'Decode Ways' problem).
   - Longest palindromic subsequence.

7. **Design Problems:**
   - Design a hit counter that counts the number of hits received in the past 5 minutes.
   - Design a data structure that supports insert, delete, and getMedian operations.
   - Implement a rate limiter.

8. **Bit Manipulation:**
   - Find the two non-repeating elements in an array where every other element appears twice.
   - Count the number of 1 bits in a binary representation of a number.
   - Determine if a number is a power of two.

**Behavioral questions** are a crucial part of software engineering interviews, as they help the interviewer assess your soft skills, work ethic, and how you handle various situations. Here are some **common behavioral questions asked in software engineering interviews**:

1. **Tell me about a time when you faced a challenging problem. How did you solve it?**
   - This question assesses your problem-solving skills and perseverance.

2. **Describe a project that you are particularly proud of. What was your role, and what was the outcome?**
   - This allows you to showcase a significant achievement and your contribution to it.

3. **Can you give an example of a time when you had to work under a tight deadline?**
   - This evaluates your time management skills and ability to handle pressure.

4. **Have you ever had a disagreement with a team member? How did you handle it?**
   - This question assesses your conflict resolution skills and ability to work in a team.

5. **Tell me about a time when you had to learn a new technology or skill quickly. How did you approach it?**
   - This evaluates your adaptability and willingness to learn.

6. **Describe a situation where you had to go above and beyond your job responsibilities.**
   - This question looks at your initiative and commitment.

7. **Can you share an experience where you had to deal with a difficult stakeholder or client?**
   - This assesses your communication skills and ability to manage relationships.

8. **Tell me about a time when you made a mistake. How did you handle it?**
   - This evaluates your accountability and ability to learn from mistakes.

9. **How do you prioritize your tasks when you have multiple projects with competing deadlines?**
   - This looks at your organizational skills and ability to manage workload.

10. **Have you ever led a team or project? What challenges did you face, and how did you overcome them?**
    - This assesses your leadership skills and ability to navigate challenges.

When answering these questions, it's essential to use the STAR (Situation, Task, Action, Result) method to structure your responses clearly and concisely. This helps you provide concrete examples and demonstrate your skills effectively.
